title: Legazpi Cathedral
text:
The Cathedral Parish of Saint Gregory the Great (), also known as Legazpi Cathedral and locally as Albay Cathedral, is a <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> <a href="cathedral">cathedral</a> dedicated to <a href="Saint%20Gregory%20the%20Great">Saint Gregory the Great</a> in the Old Albay District of the city of <a href="Legazpi%2C%20Albay">Legazpi</a>, <a href="Albay">Albay</a>, in the <a href="Bicol%20region">Bicol region</a> of the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>. It is the seat of the <a href="Diocese%20of%20Legazpi">Diocese of Legazpi</a>. In 2018, a <a href="Historical%20markers%20of%20the%20Philippines">historical marker</a> of the <a href="National%20Historical%20Commission%20of%20the%20Philippines">National Historical Commission of the Philippines</a> was unveiled at the cathedral.
History.
 The <a href="Cities%20of%20the%20Philippines">city</a> of Legazpi today was initially a <a href="barangay">barangay</a> called "Sawangan", which at present corresponds to the location of the Legazpi Port. The mission in the area, the "Mission de San Gregorio Magno de Sawangan", was founded by the <a href="Franciscan">Franciscan</a>s in 1587 as a "visita" of Cagsaua. Its first church of <a href="Nypa%20fruticans">nipa</a> and lumber was constructed which was placed under the <a href="patronage">patronage</a> of Saint Gregory the Great, the <a href="pope">pope</a> of the <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Church</a> from 590 to 604 <a href="Common%20Era">CE</a>. In 1616, it became a full pledged <a href="parish">parish</a> and was called "Albay". It was reconstructed with <a href="wood%20plank">wood plank</a>s in 1635 which was razed by fire in 1754. The first stone church was built under Fr. Pedro Romero in 1834 which was charred again during the <a href="Philippine-American%20War">Philippine-American War</a> in 1900. In 1945, parts of the church were damaged during the <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, and was subsequently repaired under Fr. Nicanor Belleza. In 1951, it became the seat and cathedral of the Legazpi Diocese upon its foundation from the territories of <a href="Archdiocese%20of%20Caceres">Diocese of Nueva Caceres</a>..
